problem_description:
Global problem:
    This problem involves a collection of items, where each have a value and a weight. We have different items given in the parameters.
    We have a infinite number of boxes with width BOX_WIDTH and height BOX_HEIGHT. All items need to be packed into minimal number of such boxes.
    The result and expected output is:
        - the assigment of each item into a box
        - the position (x and y) of each item within its assigned box. x and y have minimum values 0 and maximum infinity.

Sub problem definition - items that go in the bin - part 1:
    The items that are put into a box, must fit exactly inside the box and must not stick out of the box.
    The result and expected output is the assignment of each item into a box and the position of each item within its assigned box.

Sub problem definition - items that go in the bin - part 2:
    Taking the given items that are put into a box, they must not overlap.
    The result and expected output is the assignment of each item into a box and the position of each item within its assigned box.

Sub problem definition - items that go in the bin - part 3:
    Taking the given items that are put into a box, one item can be exactly in one box.
    The result and expected output is the assignment of each item into a box and the position of each item within its assigned box.

constants.description: List of items to be placed in the box

decision_variables.description: Number of boxes used in the end to pack all all items. Minimizing it is the objective.
Which item is assigned to which box as a separate variable.
Position x and y of each item within box as a separate variable.

constraints:
# -- Constraints --


# --- Auxiliary Variables ---
# Leave empty, if not required.
# --- constraints ---
def fit_items_in_box(
    items: DSList(length=20, elem_type=Item),
    assignments: DSList(length=20, elem_type=BoxAssignment),
    box_width: int,
    box_height: int
):
    for i in range(1, N_ITEMS + 1):
        # Ensure items fit within the box dimensions
        assert assignments[i].x + items[i].width <= box_width
        assert assignments[i].y + items[i].height <= box_height
        # Ensure positions are non-negative
        assert assignments[i].x >= 0
        assert assignments[i].y >= 0

fit_items_in_box(ITEMS, item_box_assignments, BOX_WIDTH, BOX_HEIGHT)

# Ensure box_id is within valid range
for i in range(1, N_ITEMS + 1):
    assert item_box_assignments[i].box_id >= 1
    assert item_box_assignments[i].box_id <= 20

# Set redundant fields equal
for i in range(1, N_ITEMS + 1):
    assert x_y_positions[i].box_id == item_box_assignments[i].box_id
    assert x_y_positions[i].x == item_box_assignments[i].x
    assert x_y_positions[i].y == item_box_assignments[i].y

# --- constraints ---
def no_overlap(
    items: DSList(length=20, elem_type=Item),
    assignments: DSList(length=20, elem_type=BoxAssignment),
    box_width: int,
    box_height: int
):
    for i in range(1, N_ITEMS + 1):
        for j in range(i + 1, N_ITEMS + 1):
            # Only check overlap if both items are in the same box
            if assignments[i].box_id == assignments[j].box_id:
                # Check for non-overlapping on x-axis
                x_not_overlap: bool = (
                    assignments[i].x + items[i].width <= assignments[j].x or
                    assignments[j].x + items[j].width <= assignments[i].x
                )
                # Check for non-overlapping on y-axis
                y_not_overlap: bool = (
                    assignments[i].y + items[i].height <= assignments[j].y or
                    assignments[j].y + items[j].height <= assignments[i].y
                )
                # Assert that at least one axis does not overlap
                assert x_not_overlap or y_not_overlap

no_overlap(ITEMS, item_box_assignments, BOX_WIDTH, BOX_HEIGHT)

# --- Auxiliary Variables ---
# Leave empty, if not required.
# --- constraints ---
def ensure_item_box_assignment_validity(
    items: DSList(length=20, elem_type=Item),
    assignments: DSList(length=20, elem_type=BoxAssignment),
    x_y_positions: DSList(length=20, elem_type=BoxAssignment),
    box_width: int,
    box_height: int
):
    for i in range(1, N_ITEMS + 1):
        # Ensure box_id is within valid range
        assert assignments[i].box_id >= 1
        assert assignments[i].box_id <= 20
        
        # Ensure items fit within the box dimensions
        assert assignments[i].x + items[i].width <= box_width
        assert assignments[i].y + items[i].height <= box_height
        
        # Ensure positions are non-negative
        assert assignments[i].x >= 0
        assert assignments[i].y >= 0
        
        # Set redundant fields equal
        assert x_y_positions[i].box_id == assignments[i].box_id
        assert x_y_positions[i].x == assignments[i].x
        assert x_y_positions[i].y == assignments[i].y

ensure_item_box_assignment_validity(ITEMS, item_box_assignments, x_y_positions, BOX_WIDTH, BOX_HEIGHT)

N_ITEMS : int = 20

# --- objective ---
def calculate_objective(assignments: DSList(length=20, elem_type=BoxAssignment)) -> DSInt(lb=1, ub=20):
    max_box_id: int = 0
    for i in range(1, N_ITEMS + 1):
        if assignments[i].box_id > max_box_id:
            max_box_id = assignments[i].box_id
    return max_box_id

objective = calculate_objective(item_box_assignments)
nr_used_boxes = objective
minimize(objective)

# -- Constraints --


# --- Auxiliary Variables ---
# Leave empty, if not required.
# --- constraints ---
def fit_items_in_box(
    items: DSList(length=20, elem_type=Item),
    assignments: DSList(length=20, elem_type=BoxAssignment),
    box_width: int,
    box_height: int
) -> None:
    for i in range(1, N_ITEMS + 1):
        # Ensure item fits within the box dimensions
        assert assignments[i].x + items[i].width <= box_width
        assert assignments[i].y + items[i].height <= box_height
        # Ensure item position is within box boundaries
        assert assignments[i].x >= 0
        assert assignments[i].y >= 0
        # Box id should be positive
        assert assignments[i].box_id >= 1

fit_items_in_box(ITEMS, item_box_assignments, BOX_WIDTH, BOX_HEIGHT)

# Ensure positions and assignments have matching fields
for i in range(1, N_ITEMS + 1):
    assert x_y_positions[i].box_id == item_box_assignments[i].box_id
    assert x_y_positions[i].x == item_box_assignments[i].x
    assert x_y_positions[i].y == item_box_assignments[i].y

# --- Auxiliary Variables ---
# Leave empty, if not required.
# --- constraints ---
def no_overlap(
    items: DSList(length=20, elem_type=Item),
    assignments: DSList(length=20, elem_type=BoxAssignment),
    box_width: int,
    box_height: int
) -> None:
    for i in range(1, N_ITEMS + 1):
        for j in range(i + 1, N_ITEMS + 1):
            # Only check overlap if both items are in the same box
            if assignments[i].box_id == assignments[j].box_id:
                # Check if rectangles (items) overlap
                # Overlap occurs if both horizontal and vertical projections overlap
                assert (
                    assignments[i].x + items[i].width <= assignments[j].x or
                    assignments[j].x + items[j].width <= assignments[i].x or
                    assignments[i].y + items[i].height <= assignments[j].y or
                    assignments[j].y + items[j].height <= assignments[i].y
                )

no_overlap(ITEMS, item_box_assignments, BOX_WIDTH, BOX_HEIGHT)

# Ensure positions and assignments have matching fields
for i in range(1, N_ITEMS + 1):
    assert x_y_positions[i].box_id == item_box_assignments[i].box_id
    assert x_y_positions[i].x == item_box_assignments[i].x
    assert x_y_positions[i].y == item_box_assignments[i].y

# --- Auxiliary Variables ---
# Leave empty, if not required.
# --- constraints ---
def ensure_item_box_assignment_validity(
    assignments: DSList(length=20, elem_type=BoxAssignment),
    positions: DSList(length=20, elem_type=BoxAssignment)
) -> None:
    for i in range(1, N_ITEMS + 1):
        # Ensure each item is assigned to exactly one box
        assert assignments[i].box_id >= 1
        assert assignments[i].box_id <= 20
        # Ensure positions match assignments
        assert positions[i].box_id == assignments[i].box_id
        assert positions[i].x == assignments[i].x
        assert positions[i].y == assignments[i].y

ensure_item_box_assignment_validity(item_box_assignments, x_y_positions)

) -> None:

        assert assignments[i].y + items[i].height <= box_height
        # Ensure item position is within box boundaries

        # Box id should be positive

            # Only check overlap if both items are in the same box
            if assignments[i].box_id == assignments[j].box_id:
                # Check if rectangles (items) overlap
                # Overlap occurs if both horizontal and vertical projections overlap
                assert (
                    assignments[i].x + items[i].width <= assignments[j].x or
                    assignments[j].x + items[j].width <= assignments[i].x or
                    assignments[i].y + items[i].height <= assignments[j].y or

                )

problem_description:
Global problem:
    This problem involves a collection of items, where each have a value and a weight. We have different items given in the parameters.
    We have a infinite number of boxes with width BOX_WIDTH and height BOX_HEIGHT. All items need to be packed into minimal number of such boxes.
    The result and expected output is:
        - the assigment of each item into a box
        - the position (x and y) of each item within its assigned box. x and y have minimum values 0 and maximum infinity.

Sub problem definition - items that go in the bin - part 1:
    The items that are put into a box, must fit exactly inside the box and must not stick out of the box.
    The result and expected output is the assignment of each item into a box and the position of each item within its assigned box.

Sub problem definition - items that go in the bin - part 2:
    Taking the given items that are put into a box, they must not overlap.
    The result and expected output is the assignment of each item into a box and the position of each item within its assigned box.

Sub problem definition - items that go in the bin - part 3:
    Taking the given items that are put into a box, one item can be exactly in one box.
    The result and expected output is the assignment of each item into a box and the position of each item within its assigned box.

constants.description: List of items to be placed in the box

decision_variables.description: Number of boxes used in the end to pack all all items. Minimizing it is the objective.
Which item is assigned to which box as a separate variable.
Position x and y of each item within box as a separate variable.

Global problem:
    This problem involves a collection of items, where each have a value and a weight. We have different items given in the parameters.
    We have a infinite number of boxes with width BOX_WIDTH and height BOX_HEIGHT. All items need to be packed into minimal number of such boxes.

        - the assigment of each item into a box
        - the position (x and y) of each item within its assigned box. x and y have minimum values 0 and maximum infinity.

Sub problem definition - items that go in the bin - part 1:
    The items that are put into a box, must fit exactly inside the box and must not stick out of the box.
    The result and expected output is the assignment of each item into a box and the position of each item within its assigned box.

Sub problem definition - items that go in the bin - part 2:
    Taking the given items that are put into a box, they must not overlap.
    The result and expected output is the assignment of each item into a box and the position of each item within its assigned box.

Sub problem definition - items that go in the bin - part 3:
    Taking the given items that are put into a box, one item can be exactly in one box.
    The result and expected output is the assignment of each item into a box and the position of each item within its assigned box.

):
    for i in range(1, N_ITEMS + 1):
        for j in range(i + 1, N_ITEMS + 1):
            # Only check overlap if both items are in the same box
            if assignments[i].box_id == assignments[j].box_id:
                # Check if rectangles (items) overlap

                    assignments[j].y + items[j].height <= assignments[i].y
                )
                # If both overlap in x and y direction, there is a real overlap

                assert not (overlap_x and overlap_y)

    items: DSList(length=20, elem_type=Item),
    assignments: DSList(length=20, elem_type=BoxAssignment),

    box_height: int
):
    for i in range(1, N_ITEMS + 1):
        for j in range(i + 1, N_ITEMS + 1):
            # Only check overlap if both items are in the same box
            if assignments[i].box_id == assignments[j].box_id:
                # Check if rectangles (items) overlap
                # They do NOT overlap if one is completely to the left, right, above, or below the other
                # So they DO overlap if none of these conditions hold
                overlap_x: bool = not (
                    assignments[i].x + items[i].width <= assignments[j].x or
                    assignments[j].x + items[j].width <= assignments[i].x
                )
                overlap_y: bool = not (
                    assignments[i].y + items[i].height <= assignments[j].y or
                    assignments[j].y + items[j].height <= assignments[i].y
                )
                # If both overlap in x and y direction, there is a real overlap
                # We must ensure this does not happen
                assert not (overlap_x and overlap_y)

problem_description:
Global problem:
    This problem involves a collection of items, where each have a value and a weight. We have different items given in the parameters.
    We have a infinite number of boxes with width BOX_WIDTH and height BOX_HEIGHT. All items need to be packed into minimal number of such boxes.
    The result and expected output is:
        - the assigment of each item into a box
        - the position (x and y) of each item within its assigned box. x and y have minimum values 0 and maximum infinity.

Sub problem definition - items that go in the bin - part 1:
    The items that are put into a box, must fit exactly inside the box and must not stick out of the box.
    The result and expected output is the assignment of each item into a box and the position of each item within its assigned box.

Sub problem definition - items that go in the bin - part 2:
    Taking the given items that are put into a box, they must not overlap.
    The result and expected output is the assignment of each item into a box and the position of each item within its assigned box.

Sub problem definition - items that go in the bin - part 3:
    Taking the given items that are put into a box, one item can be exactly in one box.
    The result and expected output is the assignment of each item into a box and the position of each item within its assigned box.

                # Non-overlapping condition: either i is left of j, right of j, above j, or below j

                       (positions[j].x + items[j].width <= positions[i].x) or \

problem_description:
Global problem:
    This problem involves a collection of items, where each have a value and a weight. We have different items given in the parameters.
    We have a infinite number of boxes with width BOX_WIDTH and height BOX_HEIGHT. All items need to be packed into minimal number of such boxes.
    The result and expected output is:
        - the assigment of each item into a box
        - the position (x and y) of each item within its assigned box. x and y have minimum values 0 and maximum infinity.

Sub problem definition - items that go in the bin - part 1:
    The items that are put into a box, must fit exactly inside the box and must not stick out of the box.
    The result and expected output is the assignment of each item into a box and the position of each item within its assigned box.

Sub problem definition - items that go in the bin - part 2:
    Taking the given items that are put into a box, they must not overlap.
    The result and expected output is the assignment of each item into a box and the position of each item within its assigned box.

Sub problem definition - items that go in the bin - part 3:
    Taking the given items that are put into a box, one item can be exactly in one box.
    The result and expected output is the assignment of each item into a box and the position of each item within its assigned box.

):

# --- objective ---
def calculate_objective(assignments: DSList(length=20, elem_type=DSInt(lb=1, ub=20))) -> DSInt(lb=1, ub=20):
    max_box: int = 0
    for i in range(1, N_ITEMS + 1):
        if assignments[i] > max_box:
            max_box = assignments[i]
    return max_box

objective = calculate_objective(item_box_assignments)

minimize(objective)

def items_fit_in_boxes(
    items: DSList(length=20, elem_type=Item),
    positions: DSList(length=20, elem_type=Position),
    assignments: DSList(length=20, elem_type=DSInt(lb=1, ub=20)),
    box_width: int,
    box_height: int
):
    for i in range(1, N_ITEMS + 1):
        # Ensure item fits within the box boundaries
        assert positions[i].x + items[i].width <= box_width
        assert positions[i].y + items[i].height <= box_height
        # Ensure positions are non-negative (already constrained by Position definition)
        assert positions[i].x >= 0
        assert positions[i].y >= 0

items_fit_in_boxes(ITEMS, x_y_positions, item_box_assignments, BOX_WIDTH, BOX_HEIGHT)

def no_overlap(
    items: DSList(length=20, elem_type=Item),
    positions: DSList(length=20, elem_type=Position),
    assignments: DSList(length=20, elem_type=DSInt(lb=1, ub=20))
):
    for i in range(1, N_ITEMS + 1):
        for j in range(i + 1, N_ITEMS + 1):
            # Only check overlap if both items are in the same box
            if assignments[i] == assignments[j]:
                # Check if rectangles (items) overlap
                # Not overlapping if one is to the left of the other
                # Or one is above the other
                assert (
                    positions[i].x + items[i].width <= positions[j].x or
                    positions[j].x + items[j].width <= positions[i].x or
                    positions[i].y + items[i].height <= positions[j].y or
                    positions[j].y + items[j].height <= positions[i].y
                )

no_overlap(ITEMS, x_y_positions, item_box_assignments)

problem_description:
Global problem:
    This problem involves a collection of items, where each have a value and a weight. We have different items given in the parameters.
    We have a infinite number of boxes with width BOX_WIDTH and height BOX_HEIGHT. All items need to be packed into minimal number of such boxes.
    The result and expected output is:
        - the assigment of each item into a box
        - the position (x and y) of each item within its assigned box. x and y have minimum values 0 and maximum infinity.

Sub problem definition - items that go in the bin - part 1:
    The items that are put into a box, must fit exactly inside the box and must not stick out of the box.
    The result and expected output is the assignment of each item into a box and the position of each item within its assigned box.

Sub problem definition - items that go in the bin - part 2:
    Taking the given items that are put into a box, they must not overlap.
    The result and expected output is the assignment of each item into a box and the position of each item within its assigned box.

Sub problem definition - items that go in the bin - part 3:
    Taking the given items that are put into a box, one item can be exactly in one box.
    The result and expected output is the assignment of each item into a box and the position of each item within its assigned box.

constants.description: List of items to be placed in the box

decision_variables.description: Number of boxes used to pack all items, minimized as objective
Assignment of each item to a box index
decision_variables.initialization: item_box_assignments : Annotated[list[Annotated[int, Field(strict=True, ge=1, le=20)]], Len(20, 20)]

decision_variables.description: X and Y positions of each item within its assigned box

    items: DSList(length=20, elem_type=Item),
    positions: DSList(length=20, elem_type=Position),
    assignments: DSList(length=20, elem_type=DSInt(lb=1, ub=20))
):
    for i in range(1, N_ITEMS + 1):
        item_width: int = items[i].width
        item_height: int = items[i].height
        pos_x: int = positions[i].x
        pos_y: int = positions[i].y
        assigned_box: int = assignments[i]
        
        # Ensure item fits within the box dimensions
        assert pos_x + item_width <= BOX_WIDTH
        assert pos_y + item_height <= BOX_HEIGHT
        assert pos_x >= 0
        assert pos_y >= 0
        assert assigned_box >= 1
        assert assigned_box <= 20

ensure_items_fit_in_boxes(ITEMS, x_y_positions, item_box_assignments)

# --- constraints ---
def prevent_item_overlap(
    items: DSList(length=20, elem_type=Item),
    positions: DSList(length=20, elem_type=Position),
    assignments: DSList(length=20, elem_type=DSInt(lb=1, ub=20))
):
    for i in range(1, N_ITEMS + 1):
        for j in range(i + 1, N_ITEMS + 1):
            # Only check for overlap if both items are in the same box
            if assignments[i] == assignments[j]:
                # No overlap condition: one of the following must be true
                # 1. Item i is to the left of item j
                # 2. Item i is to the right of item j
                # 3. Item i is below item j
                # 4. Item i is above item j
                assert (
                    positions[i].x + items[i].width <= positions[j].x or
                    positions[j].x + items[j].width <= positions[i].x or
                    positions[i].y + items[i].height <= positions[j].y or
                    positions[j].y + items[j].height <= positions[i].y
                )

prevent_item_overlap(ITEMS, x_y_positions, item_box_assignments)
